ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A deep understanding of magical realism and its role in Latin America. I learned to make literary commentary and how to defend my own ideas about a text.

I think that this seminar helped me in improving on my analytic skills, especially when dealing with Spanish texts. I find that reading longer texts has always been slightly difficult, and while it is still hard, Professor Echevarria was very helpful in walking us through the different books and introducing new concepts to us. I thought that learning about the magical realism genre was very interesting given that I had never heard of it prior to taking this class.
the basic ideas, history, and characteristics of  magical realism

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course is great. Books are fascinating and are paired with very enriching essays. The professor really knows what he is talking about. Getting our essays back with feedback would've been nice (addressed by the professor, and I understand it is hard for him to do so virtually).

I think that the strengths were in the teaching and the help from the TA. Professor Echevarria is very well-versed in this subject and this shows in his teaching. The weakness would just be the technological aspect. Given that all teaching is remote, this made it harder to engage at times.

strengths: professor Gonzalez Echevarria is extremely knowledgeable

weaknesses: basically a two hour lecture by the professor which can be difficult to sit through at times without student discussion

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual seminar worked out better than I thought it would. I hoped other students would've participated more. Scheduled office hours would've been nice.

the 2 hr format is definitely made less enjoyable over zoom in any class, but especially this class because there was no discussion. students basically sat in front of a computer listening to the professor lecture for 2 hrs, which could be interesting, but was at times all over the place

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! This course is quintessential in understanding Latin American literature and culture. Professor Echevarria is one of the best the department has; he picks great readings and complements them with amazing essays.

if you are very interested in magical realism, take this class. professor is extremely knowledgeable and can connect dots in history and across historical ideas and movements very well. if not, dont take it.
